At the core of everything, crypto is a set of keys. The golden rule is “whoever holds the keys, controls the crypto.” Some people don’t seem to know or care, but for those of us that do, we take key management extremely serious. And Abra doesn’t give me control over my key.

It’s an interesting concept and my issue isn’t about whether this app is good or bad, my issue is about being given misleading information. This wallet does not allow me to hold XRP. This wallet does not give me control over my private key. I expect better from Ripple and Bill.
I don’t care about his tone. I care about his message. Non-custodial wallets are in NO WAY similar to a hosted exchange. Period. He is contributing to people’s misunderstanding of crypto.
This is the first time that I’ve ever felt like @ ripple was willing to bend toward deceitfulness at the expense of users.

Crypto is keys. Whoever holds the keys, controls the crypto. Some people don’t care whether or not they hold them. Many people don’t even know what crypto is. But for those of us who want control of our crypto, we HAVE to have the keys. Period. Edge users control their keys.

Do you think it’s accurate to call Abra a non-custodial wallet? Because THAT’S why I used it. Of course having ownership of my keys is important to me. Are you kidding me with this? Crypto = keys. Not IOUs.
I don’t use exchanges. I use non-custodial wallets to hold my keys. Crypto = keys.

If I understand this correctly (and I may not), users can never be given access to their private keys. Scenario: Bitcoin is $5K and I use it to “buy” $5K of XRP. Then the price of XRP dips, but BTC doubles. The private key would give me access to the BTC (now worth $10K).

The first thing I did when I deposited Bitcoin into the wallet was exchange it for $ XRP. I didn’t have to pay the reserve fee. Why not? Then I started looking for the wallet address and there wasn’t one. There was no way to verify that I owned XRP at all. Then I learned I didn’t.

No. You’re not actually buying XRP. It only looks that way. What you’re really buying is a Bitcoin contract that tracks the price of XRP. It looks like I exchanged Bitcoin for XRP, but I don’t actually have any XRP. I have a Bitcoin contract.pic.twitter.com/QENiCZlNv2

How does this affect $XRP’s liquidity? I “bought” XRP with the app, but it turns out that actually means I bought a BITCOIN contract that tracks the price of XRP. Also, the backup recovery seed phrase is 13 words (unusable) instead of 12. That makes my spidey senses go off.
I like taunting with the “but I am paid in Bitcoin” part. It brings me joy.
We don’t hold or own XRP? Only a Bitcoin contract that tracks the price of XRP? Abra, can you confirm please?

It looks like only BTC deposits and withdrawals for now. RJ, have you figured out how to verify anything on the ledger? I exchanged Bitcoin for XRP but I didn't have to activate the wallet with a reserve and I don't see a way of verifying that I own it.
I have NEVER been paid to promote BitcoinCash or XRP. I am paid exclusively in Bitcoin though. You’re welcome.https://twitter.com/bitcoin_yoda/status/974430250875609088 …
